content:
It might be. We'd need to understand more about the specific policies. Does the 'voluntary' one supplement other policies or is it stand-alone? (EHCPOL is for supplemental policies). The definition of the code MANPOL is pretty poor (and tautological), so - as defined now - it seems like it'd be a fit for any mandatory policy. (Attention @Paul Knapp on the question and the MANPOL definition)

Also, note that the binding of Coverage.type is only 'preferred', which means you're free to use other codes from other code systems (including making up your own code system) if the set of codes definitely don't map to what you need.
Andrey Alabin has marked this topic as resolved.
